required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.official_title: Awareness & Use of Emergency Contraception Among Women Attending Kidwany MCH Center , Assiut City

brief_summary.textblock:
General objective:
To decrease the percentage of unwanted and/or unplanned pregnancies and their consequences on women's reproductive health.
Specific objectives:
1. To assess awareness of the study participants about emergency contraception.
2. Determine the percentage of ever use among the participants.
3. To identify factors that affect the awareness and use of emergency contraception among the study participants

primary_outcome.measure: Percent of awareness and use of emergency contraception
primary_outcome.description: when to use emergency contraception to prevent the unwanted pregnancy

intervention.description: know the emergency contraception and how to use

study_pop.textblock: Married women in reproductive age (15 - 49 years) clients who are attending Kidwany MCH centre, Assiut city.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Married women in reproductive age (15 - 49 years)
Exclusion Criteria:
- Infertile and postmenopausal women.

reference.citation: Mohammed S, Abdulai AM, Iddrisu OA. Pre-service knowledge, perception, and use of emergency contraception among future healthcare providers in northern Ghana. Contracept Reprod Med. 2019 Jan 24;4:1. doi: 10.1186/s40834-018-0082-9. eCollection 2019.

results_reference.citation: Mittal S. Emergency contraception: which is the best? Minerva Ginecol. 2016 Dec;68(6):687-99. Epub 2016 Apr 15. Review.
Association of Women's Health, Obstetric and Neonatal Nurses. Emergency Contraception. J Obstet Gynecol Neonatal Nurs. 2017 Nov - Dec;46(6):886-888. doi: 10.1016/j.jogn.2017.09.004.
